dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: The bus rolls on past the Arab village into the open desert once again. It looks parched and grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired of watching the sameness of the desert, Hank grows, restless. He looks about for something to do. Ben leans back against the seat and closes his eyes. Jo takes a paper-bound novel out of her bag, finds her place. Hank decides to wander down the aisle of the bus and test its possibilities for adventure. The CAMERA DOLLIES BACK with him as he rather aimlessly makes for the front of the bus,. Having left the Arab village, the bus picks up speed, and is beginning to bump and sway somewhat. When Hank is a little better than half way down the aisle, the bus sways in a particularly startling manner, causing Hank to stagger. In order to steady himself, he thrusts out his hand to grab the side of a seat. He misses the seat, and only succeeds in clutching at the veil of an Arab woman. Unfortunately, he pulls the veil from her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The startled woman, instantly horrified, covers her face with her hands and gives a sharp cry,

dialogues.text: With the bus still bumping and swaying, Hank staggers a bit without realizing that he still has, hold of the woman's veil. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 4.

dialogues.text: The woman still covers her face, but from the seat next to her, and nearer the window, an Arab rises and makes a sharp comment in Arabic to Hank. The Arab's robes are brown, with a turban-like hat combining twisted strands of white and pale green cloth, The Arab starts to move past the woman, toward Hank, repeating his demand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People look quickly toward the sound, wondering at the reason for the trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus driver scans his rear vision mirror for the source of the trouble behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank looks up at the oncoming Arab, and retreats uncertainly, not realizing he is still holding the veil.

dialogues.text: The Arab in the brown robes begins assaulting the boy in furious Arabic, indicating that he wants the veil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Arabs, and a veiled woman, rise in their seats apparently disturbed by what the brown-clothed Arab is saying. They being talking among themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and his wife, Jo, are straining from their back seat and looking down the aisle to see what is wrong. Ben looks at his wife quickly and then back, indicating that Hank is involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank retreats and squeezes himself against his mother, still with the veil in one hand. Ben faces the Arab who stops, but continues his monologue for Ben's benefit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute.     Wait a minute. Simmer down. The Arab continues pointing, talking.

dialogues.text: From a nearby seat a young Frenchman in civilian clothes rises quickly. The CAMERA PANS him to Ben and the Arab. He pushes in between the pair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Ben) Pardon me. He turns to the Arab, moves him back   a little, sharply silences his attack, and then begins,   in Arabic, to explain firmly that the boy meant, no   harm. It was an accident. The Arab isn't convinced,    points to Hank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Frenchman leans toward Hank and takes the veil he is still unconsciously holding. He hands it to the Arab with a sharp command to return to his seat. The Arab turns away carrying the veil. As the CAMERA PANS him AWAY, we see the spectators resuming their seats, growing quiet.

dialogues.text: Jo turns, and gives Ben a meaningful glance.     "The Frenchman is asking questions again."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben gives her a look of comic disparagement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis comes up, hands her a martini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.   Let's sit where it's cool. THE CAMERA PRECEDES Jo and Louis as they walk to the balcony. Ben, putting the finishing touches on his tie, watches them out of the corner of his eye. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org Jo takes a seat, and Louis leans against the railing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I was on the American stage, and the London stage, and even the Paris stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you might have seen me in Paris -- being French, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The theater, requires time, and for me time is often a luxury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been to Paris, Mr. Bernard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studies her briefly) I was born there. Jo takes a sip of her drink, with some, frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do for a living?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy and sell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever gives the best profit. She puts down     her drink with some exasperation. As she does, she     glances back toward Ben. He's getting his coat, but     pauses to give her a slight smile and a look that says     "You're wasting your time."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (More firmly) Just what are you buying, or selling, now in Marrakesh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sips   his drink) You know,   I would much rather talk about the   stage. If you tell me what to answer   any? Before he can answer, there is a KNOCK at the door, and he looks toward it. She gets to her feet, and starts for the door. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll answer it.

dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANS Jo past Ben to the door. He has just put on his coat, and turns to follow her to the door. She opens it, and standing in the corridor is a silhouetted figure. dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excusez moi, mais is cherche la chambre do Monsieur Montgomery. Jo looks at Ben helplessly, who looks over his shoulder toward Louis Bernard for help in translating the French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the McKennas turn, the man in the doorway lifts himself on tiptoe a little and gives a sharp look in the direction of Louis Bernard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man immediately turns his attention back to Ben, and begins talking in broken English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am inquiring for the room of a Monsieur Montgomery. He asked me for a drink, and l --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, there's no Montgomery here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then pardon me, monsieur, I regret disturbing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. As Ben closes the door, we see that Louis Bernard has been advancing into the room for a better look at the man in the doorway,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummy -- I can't cut this meat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it, Hank. She goes out of the room, glancing briefly at Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Ben) May I use your telephone? Ben gestures that the phone is his. The CAMERA PANS Louis to the phone, which he picks up, and begins talking in French asking first for the operator, and a certain number. Beyond that his conversation is a mystery, because his face reveals nothing. (Possibly speaks Arabic.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Louis Bernard talks on the phone, Ben goes to   pick up his drink. He comes back into the room, as JO    enter once again from the bedroom. She looks at Louis,    then at Ben who shrugs his shoulders. Louis finishes    his phone conversation, hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am terribly sorry, but I cannot go to dinner with you tonight. I had neglected an important matter which now requires my attention. Perhaps, another night... He bows briefly and moves towards the door. The McKenna's look at each other quite bewildered. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA is slowly MOVING around the interior of an Arab restaurant catering to European tourists. It has a Moorish atmosphere, and the diners are sitting on cushions or low sofas. Long-robed waiters are padding in and out from the kitchens, quietly and efficiently serving food. There are no Arab women to be seen. The air has a smoky quality, and the room is filled with the murmur of voices and the clink of dishes. Perhaps soft music of an oriental nature is heard in the background. The light is supplied principally from candles. As the CAMERA completes its sweep around and COMES TO REST on the entrance, we see Ben and Jo arriving. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 23 A headwaiter, wearing a fez, comes forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headwaiter bows slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonsoir, Madame, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening. My name is McKenna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.   The hotel phoned.   Follow me please. The headwaiter turns and moves into the restaurant, The McKennas follow him, the CAMERA PANNING them. Ben is interested in everything he sees. Jo glances at the diners, and then a look of surprise starts through her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are passing a couple who are seated on cushions eating. The couple look up at Ben and Jo. They are the same two people we saw come out of the Hotel Mamounia just as the McKennas entered. The woman had stared at Jo, and she does it again, nudging the man next to her with an elbow. The McKennas almost pass them, then stop. The woman continues half-looking over her shoulder again, then turns back to her dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headwaiter shows them to their seats -- two cushions directly behind those of the two people who stared at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you will find this comfortable. He bows and departs. Jo seems disturbed, looks around as if trying to find another seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Jo, please.   People are staring at us. She sits on the far cushion. Her movements are graceful and easy as she sits tailor fashion. Ben, being tall and somewhat awkward, has trouble. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 24 First he kneels, and then with much struggle manages to fold his long legs underneath him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to Jo, expecting to find her amused at his antics, but instead her face is serious, and she has a secret look about her. She leans close to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. People are staring at us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What people? She gives a quiet, warning nod toward the two people sitting behind them. Ben cranes his head around, but all he can see Is the back of a woman's head. He turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stared at us when we went into the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo, will you stop imagining things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben looks at her, then slowly turns his head to look behind him at the couple. As he does, the woman behind him also turns. They are staring directly at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening. Hearing her voice, Jo turns, looks, and so does the man with Mrs. Drayton. The woman then turns half way around toward Jo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must think me awfully rude. I've been staring at you ever since I saw you at the hotel. Jo slides a glance of "see" at Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (She peers at Jo) You are Jo Conway, the Jo Conway? Jo visibly relaxes and becomes Jo Conway. It's Ben's turn to give her a triumphant look in return. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org             25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I am. Mrs. Drayton turns to the man next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I tell you? I knew I was right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another angle, featuring the man, and Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Lucy Drayton, and this is my husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do. We're Mr. and Mrs. McKenna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife tells me Mrs. McKenna appeared at the London Palladium a few years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we hardly ever see a show. Edward is such an old stick-in-the- mud. So I have to console myself with your records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I must admit I love 'em. I'm not one for this terrible Bee Bop or whatever you call it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Laughs) Thank you, Mr. Drayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you coming back to London?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possibly never again, professionally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me you've given up the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Temporarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that I'm a doctor... Yes. And a doctor's wife... Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org               26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Ben means is that there are no Broadway musical shows produced in Indianapolis, Indiana. Of course, if we lived in New York... (For Ben's benefit) ...where I hear doctors aren't starving...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Jo) I have nothing against working  in New York. Nothing except the fact   that it's very hard for my patients  to come all the way from Indianapolis  for treatment. Drayton looks at his wife disapprovingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear, oh dear. I'm always saying the wrong thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the least, Mrs. Drayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me; Dr. McKenna do you always.....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think we could get straightened around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We now find the Draytons and the McKennas are  sitting in a group, eating dinner together. There is   no back to back awkwardness. All  are busily tearing  whole roast chickens apart with their bare fingers.   Drayton holds a piece of chicken aloft, demonstrating  the proper Arab method of eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the first two fingers and thumb of the right hand. Never use the smaller fingers. And always keep the left hand in the lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it have something to do with religion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More social than religious, I'd say. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems to me if you have four good fingers, and a thumb, you should use them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three finger -- four fingers -- for my money this is nothing but chicken in the rough. We have it at every drive- in back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as I was saying, I was quite happy farming my bit of land It Buckinghamshire, when these chaps from the United Nations started worrying me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward was a big noise at the Ministry of Food during the war, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I pulled myself up by the roots, and here we are. United Nations Relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds like interesting work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should see my report on soil erosion in Morocco... (Sadly) But nobody reads it. Jo is staring at the entrance to the restaurant. Mrs. Drayton follows her glance. The two men stop talking, and eating, and also look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis Bernard is standing in the entrance of the restaurant. On his arm is a rather elegantly dressed woman. She is also handsome and graceful. As he stands waiting for the headwaiter, Louis Bernard looks around the restaurant. His eyes stop when he comes to the McKennas. He looks directly at them without the slightest sign of recognition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trouvez nous un coin tranquille -- C'est possible? (Could you show me a quiet place?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainment, monsieur.   (Certainly, Sir) Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org              28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo and Ben stare back. There is resentment in Jo's eyes, and conjecture in Ben's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headwaiter comes up to Louis Bernard, exchanges a few words with him which we cannot hear, and then leads the couple to a set of cushions in the far corner of the room. As he moves away from the entrance, Louis Bernard does not look at the McKennas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the couple traverses the restaurant, our four diners watch them -- the Draytons out of idle curiosity, but the McKennas with growing astonishment as they realize that Bernard has no intention of recognizing them, or speaking to them. Jo turns back to Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well just what do you think of that? First he promises to take us to dinner --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, we only met him today. We can't expect him to change his whole life --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Ben!   What's the matter with you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing!   What's the matter with you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't like to be both privately and publicly insulted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you blame him? Turning down an old married couple for a date with a girl like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not an old married couple! All right -- He's a heel. I don't understand him -- and I'm beginning not to like what he's doing to our whole night. Drayton, quietly amused, is listening to Ben and Jo. But Mrs. Drayton is embarrassed. She makes conversation at random. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Drayton) I must do some shopping in the market tomorrow. I do hope it'll be fine. Fine, but not too fine. Of course, I how our English weather is awful, but I sometimes think we don't know when we're lucky. All this sunshine, day after day. It seems unnatural, somehow. Ben makes as if to rise, but Jo holds him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, I know you -- once you get worked up, you'll start a fight. Now please, sit down and forget him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To the McKennas) By the way, it'd be pleasant if you'd let us show you round the market place, tomorrow.

dialogues.text: Louis Bernard, the big buyer from Paris, was going to take us through the market tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Starts to rise aaain) Good. I'll just go over and cancel out. She pushes him down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, don't. Our dinner's getting cold. (To the Draytons) We'd love to go with you. Ben glares in Bernard's direction, and then picks up a chicken leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why Ben gets so worked up over unimportant things. Ben looks a her slowly, and with some amazement. Then his eyes lift a little and he sees the headwaiter standing nearby gesturing to him to please use only three fingers. Ben looks down at the chicken leg. He is holding it gripped in his fist. This is too much. He throws the leg down to his plate in disgust. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 30

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over in the far corner of the restaurant, the lady with Louis Bernard leans forward and murmurs something in French. Her gaze is across the room in the direction of the McKennas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'est les deux que cherchez? (Is that the couple you are looking for?) Louis turns slightly and looks.     He glances back at her and nods significantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oui.   (Yes.) FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: It is around eleven o'clock in the morning in the    main market square at Marrakesh. This is usually the     busy time of the day. There are coaches arriving from     the countryside with the Arab farmers alighting with    their baggage, veiled women getting off the coaches and    goin into the markets.

dialogues.text: A closer view of the shoppers -- veiled women, men on bicycles, carts and donkeys passing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The water sellers move slowly through the market, their large hats tinkling with gay sounding bells.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The medicine man sitting among his medical wares -- Ben and Jo enter and look down at the collection of claws, lizards, and barnyard scrapings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like he has a cure for everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, there's a lot of that going around these days. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 31

dialogues.text: Woman with sewing machine on head.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The bread vendors offering large fresh-baked loaves of bread. Scattered among the native populace are some tourists and perhaps some French residents.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: Mr. Drayton is standing by an Arab who has a small gambling table set up, possibly roulette, There are others gambling. After  a moment's hesitation, and a look around to see that he is safe from Mrs. Drayton, he chances a small bet.  He loses.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: An old man squatting on his heels and surrounded by a small circle of onlookers is reading from a book. His voice intones monotonously. The CAMERA PANS to the RIGHT and we see Hank McKenna standing watching him. Hank is holding on to Mrs. Drayton's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he doing, Mrs. Drayton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the teller of tales, Hank. He reads legends and famous old stories from history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish he'd say something I could understand.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: A larger group of people who are gathered around some acrobats who are performing rather well.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: Standing on the fringe of the crowd watching the acrobats are the McKennas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, I'm glad we came here. It's different, a little exciting. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 32

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you rather be in Now York -- rehearsing? She takes his arm affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, all that  talk last night was just social chit  chat, Every woman who ever gave up the  stage for marriage is supposed to  want to go back. I was just playing  a part expected of me. She pauses a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you do -- let's talk about it -- seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, if at all, let's talk about it humorously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummy!   Daddy! They turn in time to see Hank run up to them, followed by Mrs. Drayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on with us! We're gonna see the medicine man! Maybe you on learn something, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Laughs) You're probably right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Mrs. Drayton) Any time he starts wearing you out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never enjoyed the market place so much. Oh! She dashes off in pursuit of the fast-moving Hank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: Standing on the fringe of the crowd watching the acrobats are the McKennas. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, this whole market place is very different and exciting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like the county fairs when I was a kid. They'd get everything but the balloon ascension. Jo starts giggling.   Ben looks it her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That didn't sound too hilarious to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just thinking...do you know what's paying for these three days in Marrakesh? Ben chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the purse I bought in Paris... Bill Edwards' tonsils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummy!   Daddy! They turn in time to see Hank run up to them, followed by Mrs. Drayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on with us! We're gonna see the medicine man! Maybe you can learn something, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) You're probably right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Drayton) Any time he starts wearing you out... Mrs. Drayton ad Hank go out of the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know whether or not to believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, glamour is a costume I put on once. It never fit too well. I'd rather live my own life than one written for me. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including sleeping with a man who always smells of ether?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to look seductive at breakfast and worry if the Times reviewer doesn't like my scrambled eggs. Drayton appears behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are the acrobats today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh fine, fine. Haven't dropped anybody yet. Ben takes Jo's arm and they saunter off, leaving Mr. Drayton to the acrobats. They do it in such a way as to indicate the group is not hold together by any social formalities.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The CAMERA DOLLIES along beside them as they pass down a line of Arab barbers all busily engaged with shaving and cutting the hair of their customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the way home we'll be riding on Herbie Taylor's ulcors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Allida Markle's asthma. Her eyes widen a little in surprise, and somewhat hurt, at his statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know it's just a song and a dance here and there... but it's all he thinks about. Show business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, you're setting a trap for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has a good mind.   Give him a chance to develop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean give him a change to be a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 35

dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANNING through the market place to a line of veiled women all working at Singer sewing machines. Drayton saunters behind them in the distance. Jo holds out her hand for Ben to shake it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, darling, a deal's a deal. Ben takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For every time step he'll learn a new muscle -- and for every chorus, three bones. Ben can't help chuckling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And for every matinee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two chapters of Grey's Anatomy. They stop short of bumping into Hank and Mrs. Drayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mummy. (He points) Sewing machines! Looks like a television commercial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now If we could only get four cases of the Seven-year itch, we could retire. Or, if Mrs. Yarros really has triplets, we could at least redecorate the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Laughs) Oh, Ben, what would they say if they heard us?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANNING through the market place to a line of veiled women all working at Singer sewing machines. Drayton saunters behind them in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the reasons I came to a place like Marrakesh is so that we could say things like this without anybody hearing us. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                  3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to say something where nobody can hear us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the safest place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are we going to have another child? Ben looks at her with some surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the doctor.   You have all the answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- but, but this is the first time I've heard the question! They stop short of bumping into Hank and Mrs. Drayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mummy. (He points) Sewing machines! Looks like a television commercial. Jo laughs appreciatively, and rumples his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having a good time, Hank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's delighted with everything. At this moment, Mr. Drayton saunters up, and for the first time the group is all together. Suddenly there as some shouts in the distance. Everyone's attention is drawn to the noise. Hank moves quickly, threading his way through some people for a better look, the CAMERA PANNING him away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: From Hank's viewpoint we see police chasing a white- robed Arab figure. The police consist of a couple of uniformed French officials and two or three others in local Arab dress, with rifles slung over their backs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: Hank, fascinated at the drama, dishes away to got a better view. Jo and Ben miss Hank.   Then see him moving through the crowd. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank!   Hank -- come back here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank! She starts forward after him, but Mrs. Drayton moves faster than anyone. She passes both of the McKennas and overtakes Hank.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Drayton reaches down and takes hold of Hank's shoulders, and pulls him toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank, it's best to keep away from trouble. Hank is looking away toward the chase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? Mrs. Drayton looks toward the trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks as though the police are chasing somebody.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: A closer view of the chase brings us back to where the motor coaches are loading up, and for a moment the police as lost to view.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: A high view of the open air tannery with its circles of crude stone water tanks becomes the scene of a further part of the chase. We see the white-robed Arab leaping between the crude tanks with the police yelling and running after him in the distance. The difficulty of the obstacles enables the Arab to get ahead of them, and we see that he is now able to dodge through an archway into the grain market.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: As the chase passes through the grain market, it scatters grain and grain sellers in every direction. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                38.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The pursued Arab dashes through an enclosure holding the donkeys which are used to carry grain to and from the market. There is quite a stampede, with the donkeys running, kicking, and braying in fright.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: Through another archway the Arab now dashes down some of the narrow streets of the Medina. Sapling branches are laced overhead creating a latticed shadow pattern on the ground below.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: As the Arab moves along the narrow street, with the police in pursuit, progress is made difficult by the many shoppers and bicycle riders. One bicycle rider trying to avoid the oncoming Arab turns and drives helplessly into a lags pottery store. The sound of wreckage is enormous.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The Arab turns into another street where the rows of brilliantly dyed wool yarn hang, from overhead strung along sapling poles. There is in unfortunate collision between the fleeing Arab end a workman crossing the street with a large vat of blue dye on his shoulder. In a moment the whole narrow streetway is saturated with blue dye, and everyone is lifting his robe and hopping around to avoid being stained. The Arab continues on past. The police dash through the street trying to avoid the dye themselves.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The Police reach a narrow intersection where the blind beggars as squatting, begging alms. They pause. There is no sign of their quarry. Then one of them points to faint blue footprints dashing away to the left. They take up the pursuit once again.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: A high, overhead shot of the narrow streets showing that the police have caught sight of their man again. But there seems to be something strange about the chase now. Two white-robed Arabs are running. The second Arab we haven't seen before, but he is faster than the first man and is gaining on him. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                39.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: A closer, level shot, the CAMERA PANNING, shows, the two breathless men closing in on each other. As they reach an intersection in the streets, lighted by a shaft of sunlight, the new Arab comes up behind the original man being chased and whipping out a knife from under his robes, plunges it into the back of the first man. Then he turns and quickly moves away into a street on his left. The first Arab jerks his head up and backward with the sharp pain of the stabbing, Then he staggers into the dark shadows.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: A high shot shows that the stabbed man is almost out of sight for a moment so that the police continue their chase after the second man, who has swiftly darted down another side turning.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The CAMERA MOVES IN behind the stabbed Arab. The knife is still in his back. We get a glimpse of his hands, vainly groping behind him. The CAMERA MOVES WITH HIM as he staggers out into the open market place. His shadow on the ground shows us the silhouette of the knife handle sticking out from his back. The CAMERA MOVES IN CLOSE to follow the agony of his head and shoulders as he attempts to go forward.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The CAMERA seems to pass BEYOND HIM for a moment, and there, a few yards away, stands Ben McKenna, and his group.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The Arab hesitates for  a moment, but the attitude of his head shows us that  he has seen McKenna. He makes his way desperately and  painfully toward him. He is finding it difficult to  remain upright and even take those last few steps.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: A closer view  of McKenna shows that those around him, including his  wife and the Draytons, become frightened. He spreads his  arms out to move them back protectively, waiting to see  what is going to happen. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                  4

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: As the Arab reaches McKenna, the knife drops from his back, and he collapses at Ben's feet. Ben endeavors to grab him as he falls. He misses his shoulders, and his hands close in and inadvertently grab the Arab's cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: A big close up of Ben's hands as his fingers slide off the Arab's face. He turns his hands up and we see they are covered with black grease paint.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The Arab's head his now dropped to the ground, and we see streaks of white flesh showing through the dark makeup which Ben's fingers had scraped off.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: Ben drops to his knees to examine the man better.   The Arab gasps out something in French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ils ont trouvs... ils ont russi  trouver... Ben looks at him puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (English) McKenna... I'm... Louis.... Bernard. Ben is quite surprised.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: Ben glances swiftly at the fallen knife, and then reaches across Louis Bernard to turn him over and examine his wound. But the Frenchman reaches up with one arm and grabs Ben by the coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McKenna -- listen to me -- first! With what strength he has, Louis drags Ben down until Ben's ear is near to his mouth. With a great effort Louis whispers to him. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: A big closeup of Ben's ear and Louis' mouth enables us to hear the whispering, but Louis' voice is fading so much that we cannot distinguish the words -- at least enough to make any sense out of what he says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man...a statesman...is to be killed...assassinated...in London...soon...very soon...tell them...in London...to try Ambrose Chappell... Presently, the mouth stops speaking.    It remains still and open.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: As Ben backs away, we see the staring eyes, and open mouth of Louis. Ben quickly puts his hand inside the robes to feel for Louis' heart, The hand slowly withdraws. Ben rises.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The Arabs crowd in to see the details. Louis Bernard, the McKennas and the Draytons are in the center of a large flat cement section of the market place. The Police by now have caught up to the event, and dash quickly into the picture toward Ben and Louis. Instinctively Ben backs away, as do the Draytons, and Jo and Hank. However, Ben still stays closer than the rest. One of the police picks up the knife and examines it, another bends down to wipe the make-up off Louis Bernard's face. Ben looks around for his wife.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: Ben beckons to his wife beyond him, to join him. Jo turns Hank over to Mrs. Drayton. Hank stands close to the English woman as Jo comes over. As Jo comes up to Ben, he is feeling in his pocket for something. Takes out a pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben -- who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis Bernard. Got something to write on? She begins looking in her purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he dead? Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 42

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Impatiently) Yes. Yes. He's dead. She   produces a small address book. Ben snatches it out   of her hand unceremoniously. He opens the book end   begins writing something down fast. Jo watches him   with mystified curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: Drayton strolls up, out of curiosity. He has also seen Ben's hurried writing, but Ben casually puts the notebook back into his inside pocket, along with the pen. Before either man can comment on the writing, the voice of a policeman is heard, speaking in French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Savez vous qui est cet homme? The uniformed French policeman approaches Ben.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The policeman repeats his question as he stops in front of Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J'ai dit: Savez vous qui est cet homme? Drayton steps forward to help.   He addresses the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Il ne parle pas francais.   Je traduiri. The policeman nods.   Drayton turns to Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to find out if you know this man. The policeman watches their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we know him! (She points) It's the frenchman, Louis Bernard. Her gestures, and her comments, although In English, give the policeman all the information he needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looks at body) Louis Bernard? He moves away toward the body, which the other policemen are now covering with a sheet. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                43. He gives them some instructions in French. Ben looks at Jo in a way that says "Who asked you to say anything." The French policeman returns to the group.    He addresse Drayton.

dialogues.text: Quel est le nom de ces personnes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McKenna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dites leur que j'aimerai qu'ils viennent tous les deux au commissariat pour faire un rapport. Drayton nods unhappily, and turns to Ben and Jo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as I thought. He wants both of you to go to police headquarters to make a statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so. (He turns to wife) Our friends here have to go to the police Station. I'm going with them to give what help I can.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Drayton comes up to the group, still holding on to Hank's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want your little boy to go, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna go. I never saw a French police station before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps it would be best if I took him back to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very thoughtful. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org               44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ameneles aux Bureaux de Police. (He moves out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Ben) I think we'd better set off. (To wife wryly) Heaven knows how long we shall be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alons-y.   Sil vous plait. Police Two moves across the square with Drayton. Ben and Jo precede them. Drayton begins conversing in French with them about the crime, but we cannot distinguish their words clearly. Jo looks back and gives a little wave to Hank.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: The McKenna's are walking across the square with the Police and Drayton a few yards behind them. The CAMERA MOVES with them. Jo moves close to Ben and speaks to him in a surreptitious manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should he suddenly turn up in Arab- outfit, wearing makeup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's more important -- why was he killed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet he was a spy, or something like that. Ben looks at her with some surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, what did he whisper to you?    What did you write down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you later. Ben looks at his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel very good after what I said about Louis Bernard last night. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 45 JO looks away, equally embarrassed.    Ben wipes his fingers with his handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The main hallway and waiting room of the Police Station in Marrakesh. French and Arab personnel move up and down the wide hallway from one doorway to another. There is a babble of voices and the sound of phones heard off. The McKennas and Drayton are seated on a long bench, waiting to be called into the inner office of the Police Inspector. Drayton sits next to Ben. It is hot. Jo has eyes for everything, but Ben seems to be somewhat impatient. He looks at his watch for the third or fourth time in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drayton notices him studying his watch. He leans to him, and at the same time wipes off the side of his on face with a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once we talk to the police inspector, I'll do my best to out some of the red tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to stretch. She gets up and saunters away, looking around the police station for whatever there is to see. Drayton speaks to Ben with reassuring geniality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid the questions will go on till doomsday, if you admit knew this chap Bernard before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know him at all.     We only met yesterday on a bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're a cynical lot, these French -- they might refuse to believe that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll have to believe me.     It's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might sound a bit odd,    from their point of view. They saw     the poor chap whispering to you ... and    then they saw you writing something    down... Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                46. Ben looks at Drayton, waiting for his to go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question is, are you going to show them what you wrote down? Before Ben can say any more, a policeman opens the door leading to the Police Inspector's office. He calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo turns around at the sound of the door opening, and Ben and Drayton start to rise from the bench. The policeman steps aside, holding the door, as a Police Inspector comes out of the office from behind him. He is a short, heavy-built-dark man. He does not smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector walks a few steps into the corridor, stops. Ben, Jo and Drayton approach him. Drayton speaks first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ces personnes sont mes bons amis, les McKenna. Mon nom est Drayton. Ils ne parlent pas francais et ils m'ont demand de traduire. The Inspector answers in English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Monsieur Drayton, but a translator will not be necessary. (To McKenna) Won't you come inside, Monsieur, Madame? He stops aside, and wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Drayton) Do to the kindness to wait. I might have questions for you later. He motions to the McKennas. Jo goes past him first, into the office, followed by Ben, Drayton returns to the bench, and watches the trio as the office door closes on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A medium-sized office, saved from plainness of civil service decor by a few personal decorations of the Inspector. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org              47. He waves the McKenna to chairs, as he goes around behind his desk and remains standing. Ben and Jo sit down. The Inspector looks at some papers on his desk, then holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Precisely) Your passports, please. Ben looks at Jo, who fishes for them in her purse. She takes them out, hands them to Ben, who hands them to the Inspector. He scrutinizes them. Uncomfortable, Ben retreats to a chair and sits down, waiting. The inspector checks the pictures against the people he sees sitting in his office, then puts the passports down on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You entered French Morocco four days ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a doctor, monsieur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A surgeon.    A tourist, and an American citizen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three good reasons why you should have nothing in common with Louis Bernard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were recently in Paris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A medical convention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come to   Marrakesh with him in the same bus.    You drank an apritif with him in your   hotel room. And you ate at the same   restaurant last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But at different tables. The Inspector's eyes study her briefly, as if her comment was an unnecessary interruption. Then his eyes return to Ben. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org               48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Louis Bernard is a stranger to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met him yesterday -- on the bus -- for the first time in my life. The Inspector begins to let his skepticism be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ironically) And yet -- out of five  thousand people -- In a great market place  -- he comes to you when he is about to  die! Is that the action of a casual  acquaintance, monsieur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Obstinate) I know nothing about Louis Bernard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Not even, I suppose, that he was an agent of the Duxieme Bureau?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you have also never head of the American F.B.I.? (Sadly) It would be so much more easy for both of us, monsieur, if you would cease to pretend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, look here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Patiently) The dead man found out what he had been sent here to discover. That is why he was kill-ed. He told you what he had discovered. Why? Because he placed complete confidence in you. Voila.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, you not only ask the questions you also answer them -- Wait a minute let me ask you a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, Monsieur? Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assuming Bernard trusted me as implicitly as you say, I would never reveal anything he said to me, would

dialogues.text: Even Americans, I suppose, sometimes find it desirable to betray a confidence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get something straight. I'm a tourist traveling for pleasure. I somehow got involved in an unfortunate incident. I came down here to make a simple statement of fact, and not to be subjected to a police grilling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur, I would like....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Interrupting) Now hold your horses!   Just hold them. The door opens suddenly.   The two men look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A policeman opens the door and leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspecteur. On demande Monsieur McKenna au tlphone. As he speaks, the policeman nods in the direction of Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector impatiently tries to dismiss the officer with a gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laissez nous, nous sommes occuppes. Ben motions to the policeman to stay where he is

dialogues.text: Wait a minute. A telephone call for me? The policeman at the door looks at the Inspector briefly. The Inspector is disconcerted, but doesn't tell the man what to say, so he turns back to Ben and nods. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take the call now.    You just take it easy. He goes out the door, closing it behind him. The Inspector sits down heavily. Then he looks up at Jo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame McKenna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know a thing,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: The policeman enters the small office   first. There is a desk, more like a table, and a phone   is lying on it off the hook. The policeman picks it    up, and hands it to Ben. dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.text: A robed Arab is sitting in a chair holding a telephone. The room is part of a rather elaborate Moorish house. The Arab speaks in accented English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor McKenna? Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 51

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ben answers, he idly looks through the open doorway toward Drayton sitting on the bench outside.

dialogues.text: The Arab doesn't bother to identify himself.

dialogues.text: You tell  even one word of that Louis Bernard  whispered to you in the market- place --  your little boy will be in serious  danger. The Arab starts to hang up.

dialogues.text: There is an audible click in the receiver held in Ben's hand.

He stands a brief moment in thought, then half turns toward Drayton sitting in the corridor outside. He motions to Drayton to join him in the office

dialogues.text: As Ben enters the office, both Jo and the Inspector look up him inquiringly.

dialogues.text: Who was it, Ben? Ben adopts as casual an air as he can under the circumstances. He doesn't sit down. He speaks more to the Inspector than to his wife, avoiding her eyes.

dialogues.text: It was the Concierge at the Hotel. He heard we were being held by the Police and thought there was some way he could help us.

dialogues.text: (Looking at Inspector) I told him if we weren't back there in fifteen minutes to call the American Consulate in Casablanca. The Inspector has realised that he won't get any more out of Ben.

dialogues.text: Let's go, Jo.

dialogues.text: If it doesn't take too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Ben... Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 54 He gives her a warning glance to be quiet.   She does. He reaches out, takes her hand.

dialogues.text: Ben and Jo are riding along in an open Victoria, headed back for the Hotel Mamounia. Ben seems preoccupied with his thoughts.

dialogues.text: (Holds out her hand) Let me see the message.

dialogues.text: I don't -- I don't think you should. She holds out her hand more firmly.

dialogues.text: I'm your wife, Ben -- not the police inspector. Let's see it. Reluctantly, Ben takes out the notebook, hands it to her. Ben watches her as she reads the note he has written. The notebook page held by Jo on which Ben has scribbled Louis Bernard's message. It reads: "A MAN...A

dialogues.text: (Interrupts) ...is at stake, I know, But I'm not sure of what's the right thing to do. She closes the notebook. Ben reaches over, takes it from her and replaces it in his pocket. dialogues.text: I thought we ought to go back to the hotel, pack our clothes, take Hank, and get out of this country as quickly as we can.

dialogues.text: (Thinking) Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank, seeing a man killed in front of him. What a shook it must be to his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quietly) I know.

dialogues.text: Why don't you just give that note to the American Consulate -- Why get any more involved? Ben is uncomfortable, and unhappy, but he tries to hide it. He leans toward Jo as if he's about to tell her something important. He reaches out, places his hand over hers.

dialogues.text: Jo...about Hank... (He trails off)

dialogues.text: What about him?
