dialogues.text: I suppose you've heard of him.    Louis Bernard. A Frenchman. CHAPPELL JR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis Bernard? He seems to be turning the name over in his mind.    Ben turns to at the workmen around them. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 92

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The workmen half-listening, return to their work on the various animals. They are a bit self-conscious at being observed eavesdropping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben turns back to Chappell Jr. He moves in a little closer, and drops his voice somewhat. Chappell Jr. watches him warily. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's stop fencing with words, huh? Bernard told me to come here, just before he died. CHAPPELL JR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man is...dead? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it as well as I do. Now I came to make a business proposition. And I don't see how you can turn it down. Ambrose Chappell looks over to a man stuffing animal's corpse. CHAPPEEL JR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you have in mind? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to talk here? CHAPPELL JR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly. We have no secrets from our employees. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. First of all, I haven't uttered one word of what Bernard told to before he died. And I won't. Frankly I'm not interested in political intrigue, and I don't care who it is you're going to kill here in London. All I want is that boy, and I'll get on the first plane for America. When Ben begins mentioning a killing, Chappell Jr's face takes on a look of alarm, almost panic. He moves back from Ben, watching him like a deadly cobra. Ben, however, now convinced that he has the right man in front of him, moves in on him to finish his proposition. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that isn't all.   If money will do anything... Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 93

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chappell Jr. now seems thoroughly frightened. He moves back from Ben, almost stumbling. He turns, goes back to the door of a small office, in which is now standing Chappell Sr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chappell Sr. leans closer to the open door, as the son speaks urgently and sotto Voce to him. CHAPPELL JR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father -- phone the police!   Quick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chappell Jr. now turns back toward Ben, trying to assume a pleasant and casual manner. CHAPPELL JR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, sir -- shall we go into this a little more carefully? You said something about money? Workmen are pausing in their work to look at the pair, wondering at the mention of money. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told him to call the police.   Now don't try to bluff me like that! He reaches out quickly, grabs Chappell jr. by the label. The man gives an involuntary cry of fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chappell Sr. is on the phone. CHAPPELL SR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Ambrose Chappell's -- Burdett Street. Will you send someone round at once? (Glancing toward him) There's is an extraordinary individual here, and we really can't cope with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chappell Jr. struggles to get loose from Ben's grasp. CHAPPELL JR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go! Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org               94. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know Louis Bernard? CHAPPELL JR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never heard of him. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't have any idea what went on in Marrakesh yesterday, or where my boy is? CHAPPELL JR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not! Edgar!   William! Davis! Help! Ben lets go of Chappell Jr., and turns in confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The workmen drop their tools, and move in on Ben quickly and threateningly. Even Chappell Sr. comes out of the office in alarm. Ben backs away toward the door. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now just a minute. Take it easy. I obviously got the wrong place. Now stay away from me. But they don't. They come on. Ben looks quickly around for a weapon, or an exit. He sees the door, and moves quickly toward it, but the workmen are faster than he is. Two of them bar the exit. Ben tries to shove them out of the way and get through the door. The men grapple with him. Chappell Jr., himself, and another workman rush in, endeavoring to subdue Ben. A silent, but furious struggle ensues. It is now a complete melee between the four men and Ben as they try to hold him down. CHAPPELL JR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold him...hold him...till the police come. Ben breaks loose temporarily, trying to find another escape. He realizes that the time for talking is past. But as fast as he is, the men are on him again. They twist and struggle through the stuffed and mounted animals. There is a melange of lion heads, swordfish, and other partially completed jobs. Sometimes, Ben in his struggles comes face to face with the angry head of a bared-teeth lion. Ambrose Chappell Jr. himself at one point finds the swordfish a very painful object somewhere about his anatomy. Ben eventually wrenches himself free. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 95

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting toward the doorway. The confusion  gives him a free moment. He makes the door, twists it  open, and dashes out into the yard. Suddenly he turns  back and dashes in again. The man retreat in fear.   Ben picks up his fallen hat and dashes out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five persons in the McKenna suits are sitting around. All but Jo have drinks in their hands. She seems to be absorbed in her own thoughts, but Val Parnell is holding forth, oblivious at first to her disinterest. VAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and back at our flat, after the first night, Chris had the nerve to suggest that the sketch where Bud Flanagan comes in dressed up as the Countess was unconvincing ... that no matter how well-got-up Bud Flanagan was, even if he were dressed by Hartnell, nobody would believe he was an aristocrat. So I said, 'Look Chris, why don't you cut William Hickey's column out of the paper?! -- He stops talking, as he looks across at the silent Jo. Helen and the others, follow his look. They watch her sympathetically. Jo  seems totally unaware that anyone else is in the room, staring, into thin air, absorbed with thoughts of her own. VAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Softly) Jo. Jo. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? VAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's become of that unpredictable husband of yours? (Consults his watch) He's been gone over an hour. She doesn't answer, so he goes on. VAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was it he went to see?   Some man named... (Looks at group for help) ...what was it...Church? Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly Jo's expression begins to chance to one of interest. We see a flood of thoughts expressed in her face. She looks across at Val and replies: JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   No...you mean Chappell! She rises from her chair with some excitement.    She murmurs, almost to herself: JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a man, it's a place! Ambrose Chapel! Ambrose Chapel! It has to be!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others watch Jo, puzzled at her strange performance. No one dares speak until she finds out what it means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With some excitement, Jo addresses Val Parnell. J0

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they list chapels in the London Telephone Directory? VAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's a take a look. He crosses to the telephone desk, picks up telephone directory and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT of telephone directory - Val's finger lands on 'Ambrose Chapel, 17 Ambrose Street, West Two.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Excitedly) Here it is, Ambrose Chapel, 17 Ambrose Street, West Two. He turns triumphantly to Jo. Without hesitation she crosses to a table, takes her purse. She hurries to the door without a word; then turns to them. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 97 JO (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But have another drink -- and please explain to Ben when he comes in. She hurries out the door. The others are left standing, looking at each other. Val and Helen speak almost at the same time, asking each other the same question. VAL AND HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explain what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo hurrying down street towards chapel seen in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo enters and stares off at the chapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of chapel as seen by Jo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo wondering if this really is the right place. She decides she had better phone Ben and turns out of SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Parnell party are still wondering what all this is about. CINDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something weird going on around here that I can't follow. VAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see if we can figure this out. First of all there was a man named to uh... HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ambrose Chapel. CINDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Ben rushed off to see him. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 98 HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Jo said it wasn't a man, but a place and she dashed off. JAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mention it again or I might dash off. CINDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a temptation. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you fathom it, Val? Val paces thoughtfully, and they watch him. VAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be a now American gag.    I'll ask Danny about it. At that moment the door suddenly opens. Everyone turns in surprise. Ben is standing in the doorway. He comes slowly into the room, closing the door. He is very tired looking, and disheveled. They watch him enter silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too tired to say anything at first, Ben drops into the first chair he comes to. Then he looks up. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Jo? Val walks over to him, hands him a ready-made drink. Ben takes it but doesn't have time to drink when Val speaks. VAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just gone off to Ambrose Chapel. Immediately Ben puts down the drink. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But -- but, that's where I've been... He stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't your Ambrose Chapel! Ben looks at him questioningly. HELEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't a he! It's an it!     A building. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 99 CINDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just gone there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben studies the group trying to appraise in his mind what they have said. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it!     What's the address? Val crosses to find the phone book on the desk and looks for address. VAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 Ambrose Street, Bayswater. Ben moves quickly to the door and goes out into corridor as telephone rings. Jan answers it. She puts down the receiver and shouts out to Ben. JAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor! Doctor!      It's Jo!   Come back -- it's Jo. Ben comes quickly into the room pushing his way through everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes immediately to the phone.    Jan hands Ben the receiver. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo is overjoyed to hear Ben's voice. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben -- Ben, darling...what happened -- did you find anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I drew a complete blank. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                100

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it must be the chapel - and I've found it, Ben. It's just a short way from here. It was a crazy thing to do --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Interrupting hurriedly) I have the address, Jo. Now stay there until I get there...and don't do anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo loses some of her anxiety. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll meet you outside. She hangs up, sighs and starts out of the phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben hangs up the phone and starts for the door. He looks back at the group as he pauses in doorway. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you stick around? We'll be back as soon as we can. I don't know how to thank you. He goes out through the door closing it.    Everyone stands staring at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo stands watching something across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Jo's viewpoint, the exterior of Ambrose Chapel. An old building, silent and deserted. A faded sign outside identifies it. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A non-conformist Chapel. Empty, except for    one figure, a woman laying out music on the organ rack   in the front of the Chapel. The CAMERA MOVES IN on her,    and as she turns on her way to the hymn board, we see   that she is Mrs. Drayton. At the hymn board, she slips    into it a series of hymn numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA THEN PANS her across the empty chapel to a side door. She goes through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes up a flight of stairs, the CAMERA MOVING with her. She stops at a door on the first landing, takes a key out of her pocket, and unlocks the door. She enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside of a small, almost bare room, Mrs. Drayton closes the door behind her and stands with her back to it, watching. The CAMERA PANS SLIGHTLY to reveal the rest of the room. Sitting at a small table is a listless, young Hank McKenna. He is playing checkers with the woman we saw at the airport who was standing with the autograph hunters, watching Jo McKenna. The one with the dirty glasses, who made a phone call. Hank has caught the woman in a checker trap, and with obvious satisfaction jumps three of her men. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three men! You don't know much about checkers, do you? MRS. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time you went to bed, dear.    You'll get tired out. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I finish? I'm winning? MRS. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you finish. Edna, see that he gets some milk and biscuits. EDNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he'd better have another sleeping pill...I've got to get downstairs -- MRS. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Hank) You'll go to sleep, Hank, won't you? Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org               102. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so. EDNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up if you want to finish this game. MRS. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look it doesn't hurt to be kind. Yell out when you want me to open the door. Edna studies the board with a frown.   Mrs. Drayton smiles and goes out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the corridor once again Mrs. Drayton locks the door, and crosses the hall. The CAMERA PANNING her. She enters another door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She enters a larger, more ornate room. The CAMERA PANS her in, and we see first Drayton, who is putting on a surplice -- and then the man who knocked on the McKennas' door in the Mamounia Hotel, looking for someone named Montgomery. He is putting on a tie and tuxedo. He wears a dangerous-looking revolver strapped underneath his armpit; Mrs. Drayton, without a word, sits down and lights a cigarette, exhaling with something close to fatigue. Then she speaks. MRS. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish it was tomorrow. Drayton turns, having finished his dressing. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Coldly) That's not a very orthodox sentiment. He goes to a desk, and takes something out of a drawer. It is a small envelope. He turns to the man with the gun. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two excellent tickets for the concert at the Albert Hall -- with my compliments. He hands them to Rien. Rien takes the envelope, glances at it briefly, then puts it into his pocket. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your box is nicely placed, or shall we say strategically placed. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org              103. He goes to a portable record player, which is open and has a record on it. He looks down at the phonograph. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now for the most important part. He gestured towards the record. RIEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A record of the delightful Picco they will play tonight. RIEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it? DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music is less in your line than marksmanship. If you will listen, my friend, I will play for you the exact moment at which you can shoot. Now listen carefully. Drayton plays the record. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me do it for you again.   Now listen for the cymbal crash. Drayton plays the record again and claps his hands together at the cymbal crash. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see at such a moment your shot will not be heard. The listeners will not even be disturbed. I think the composer would have appreciated that. No one will know. RIEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None except one you mean. The assassin smiles. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yes -- if you are clever, my friend. Any questions musical or otherwise? RIEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's's one comforting thought. It happens early in the evening. I hope I won't upset you if I say there's time for one shot only. If you need another, the risk is yours. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                104 RIEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not take risks. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a comfort -- traipsing all the way down to Marrakesh to fetch you I should like you to do me credit. He looks at his watch. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your distinguished target's on the way there now. A car is waiting for you downstairs at the back entrance. You will pick up a Miss Benson on your way. She will be your companion in the box. She's there to lend an air of respectability...if that's possible. RIEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will have the money when I return? DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you can trust me. RIEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking him up and down) What is your English proverb -- a wolf in Sheep's clothing? Drayton laughs. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you    had better be going. It is impolite    to be late for a concert. It would be    awkward if they made you wait until    the first selection is over. He turns to his wife. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See him downstairs, my dear. (To Rien) I'm sorry you must sneak out the back way, but we have to preserve our respectable front. She exits with the assassin.    Drayton turns to the mirror and surveys himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance Jo is seen pacing. To rear door of the chapel opens and Mrs. Drayton pushes Rien out. He crosses and enters a waiting car. The car drives off. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shadows of the day are lengthening as Ben gets out of a taxi and approaches Jo standing on the sidewalk. His fatigue of before seems to have vanished in his eagerness to meet Jo and find out what she knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben comes up to her.   She grips his hands. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it is. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may have just hit it right on the nose. You can't be farther wrong than I was with my Ambrose Chapel. Let's go. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, should we get some help from the police? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, honey, please, no -- let's take a crack at this alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chapel as seen from their viewpoint. People are now entering it, but it seem as if the tag end of the congregation is entering, because the service is obviously under way, the sound of hymn singing coming across faintly to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben takes her hand, squeezes it affectionately. Together they cross the street, the CAMERA PANNING them up the steps of the chapel and to the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the Chapel from the rear, looking around cautiously. A hymn is in progress. The Chapel holds about three hundred people. It is of the non-conformist type and the congregation consists mostly of middle- aged and elderly women. Although the McKennas are not aware of it, we notice that the organist is none other than Edna, the woman who observed Jo at the airport, and later took care of Hank. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org              106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carefully the McKennas find their way to a back row seat. One or two of the women in the back row turn to look at the new arrivals. Jo wants to whisper something to Ben, but with a gesture he silences her. Ben picks up hymnal, hands her one, finds the right page and begins to sing along with the hymn. But instead of following the words of the hymn, Ben makes up his own words to communicate with Jo, as he looks around at the chapel. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) This looks like mother wild goose chase. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Singing them) Let's wait and look around... Some of the parishioners turn and listen to Jo's voice because it has a professional quality that rises above the rest. Whether they are watching her in suspicion, or admiration, is hard to tell. Jo turns her attention to the hymn book, trying to be unnoticed. Ben's eyes catch something coming down the aisle. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Singing) Look who's coming down the aisle. Jo follows his glance, leaning forward a little and to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming up the aisle with a collection basket, collecting money during the hymn is Mrs. Drayton. She is approaching the row in which the McKennas are standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo looks towards Ben helplessly. Mrs. Drayton is between the two of them and any possible exit. Ben immediately eases his way along behind a column which hides him somewhat from the front, but not from the side. Jo endeavors to shrink her body behind a tall woman in front of her, but she is not entirely successful. We can see Mrs. Drayton getting closer to them. Jo looks toward Ben almost panicked. Suddenly Mrs. Drayton has reached the end of their row. She pushes forward her collection plate, and as she does so her face blanches. She instantly identifies the two. Ben, with little else to do, looks her straight in the eye and puts some coins into her plate. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the astonished Mrs. Drayton turns to go back down the aisle with her plate of coins and bills, we now see the surpliced Mr. Drayton ascending the pulpit. He looks down to his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Mr. Drayton's viewpoint, as he notices his wife coming up the aisle with a startled expression on her face. She tries to  nod with her head to indicate something important lies behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Drayton, trying to puzzle out her alarm, studies her face, and then lifts his eyes to look beyond her. The expression on his face leaves no doubt that he cannot understand what she's trying to convey. The hymn has come an end, and the congregation starts seating itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The McKennas take a seat along with the rest, and as yet they are relatively inconspicuous from the front of the chapel. Ben takes a piece of paper out of his pocket, examines it, and satisfied it is the right one, hands it to his wife. The congregation falls silent as Drayton is apparently about to begin his sermon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drayton glances down to his Bible, opens it a certain page, and as he does so, he looks at his wife who is sitting near the organ. She half-turns to look up at him. She seems frightened. Drayton fumbles with the pages of the Bible, apparently trying to make something out of his wife's attitude. Failing, he looks up and begins his sermon. He speaks into a microphone. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brothers and Sisters: The subject of my address this evening is adversity. The average life, yours and mine, is often harassed and perplexed by cruelties and disappointments beyond our control. Strangely enough, it is often the things beyond our control which help to make us better beings. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 10 Pain and tribulation are the testing ground of   life and let us be grateful for them. Let us bless    the disappointments and the frustrations and say a   prayer for the agony of the moment. Only thus shall    we confir and re-confirm our own goodness and therefore   the essential goodness of all Mankind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half-glancing at Drayton as he delivers his sermon. Ben talks to Jo. Their conversation is whispered. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Buchanan's phone number. Go on out and call him and ask him to surround the place with police. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if he asks me... BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him...tell him everything. This is the time. I'm sure Hank is around here some place. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, I don't want to leave you. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how else to do it, honey. Ben gives her a gentle push. With a regretful look at him, she slides out of the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of his sermon, Drayton looks up. He almost falters and stops, as he sees Jo rise from her seat. The chapel as seen from Drayton's viewpoint. Jo has turned up the aisle and gone out the door at the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drayton composes his face, but his eyes are serious. Without the slightest pause, he continues his sermon, shifting his ideas in mid-paragraph. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Few of us pause to think how life's adversities work in our behalf, to make better men and women of us. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 10 DRAYTON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I believe we should pause now to do a little stock-taking -- to look into our own hearts and see what we find there. Therefore instead of continuing the service, I think we should all return to our homes for private meditation, remembering how little we have to complain of and how much to be grateful for. Next week I shall discuss the fruits of our meditation. Until then, my blessing upon each and every one of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben watches Drayton, with little charity in his heart. There is a stir in the congregation when Drayton tells them to go home. They look at each other, uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drayton closes the Bible, and begins to descend from the pulpit. The congregation comes to life. The members rise from their seats and begin filing out of the chapel. Occasionally they cast backward glances toward the pulpit, as if surprised at what they have heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Drayton reaches the two steps of the altar, he beckons the organist to him. She comes, and he whispers something to her. He then motions his wife nearer to him, and also whispers something to her. Mrs. Drayton goes off through a side door by the altar, while the organist makes her way down the aisle through the congregation to stand by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANS Ben as he threads his way up through the women who are filing out. Drayton stands at the front of the chapel, waiting. Finally, after a slow and deliberate walk up the now nearly empty chapel, Ben comes face to face with Drayton. Drayton greets him with bland amiability. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well this is a pleasant surprise, Doctor. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my boy, Drayton? Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 11 DRAYTON

dialogues.text: He's upstairs. As a matter of fact you've just come in time to help my wife with Hank's food. Seems Hank doesn't care much for English cooking. Drayton's eyes stray to the back of the church as he talks. Ben, noticing Drayton's eye movement, follows it cautiously. But before he can confirm his suspicions, there is a loud clang of a door closing that gives him his answer. He looks around quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the other end of the chapel, the woman, Edna, has just closed the door, and is in the process of locking the heavy iron lock with a large key. She extracts the key and puts it into her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben turns back to Drayton to find that his manner has changed somewhat. He grabs him quickly by the throat of his robes. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want? I'll give you money and keep my mouth shut. All I want is my boy. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about your wife? Did she go outside just to get some fresh air. BEN

dialogues.text: Tell me what you want.   I'll do anything. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- you'll see your boy in good time. With a sudden twist, he wrenches himself away from Ben. He reaches for a button on the altar, presses it. Instantly the door by the side of the altar opens and two rather strong men appear. Ben turns alertly to face them, backing of a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the men is obviously the chauffeur type, and the other one, a handyman type in his shirtsleeves. Ben takes this in, and notices the open door behind them. Ben maneuvers himself toward the pulpit, and suddenly dashes for the steps. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 11 He surprises them with his speed, and before anyone can stop him, he is in the pulpit. He grabs the microphone previously used by Drayton in his sermon. He yells into it. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank! Hank McKenna!    Hank!   Where are you? Hank! Hank! As the sound roars through he chapel the two man dash for the pulpit, and at that mount we hear, faintly off, the voice of Hank: HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy!   Daddy, I'm here!   Dad - His voice is choked off. Ben jumps down from the pulpit in an effort to make for the open door, but the two men throw themselves on top of him.

Between the CAMERA and the Poster a taxi pulls up. It is near enough to the CAMERA so that just the driver and the door fills the screen, Jo McKenna steps out the far side and pays off the driver with a Ten Shilling Note. She hurries away. The driver endeavors to call after her as he turns the note around in his hand. He looks at it with satisfaction, and stuffs it into the inner recesses of his clothes. dialogues.text: The woodwinds -- the same sound effect.

dialogues.text: Jo turns slowly and looks up at the dignitary's box. He is turning to the man beside him, whom we shall later know as the Ambassador, and indicates with gestures how much he is enjoying the concert. He looks back over his shoulder and gives the same gestures and comments to 'Buchanan'. Then, turning forward, he settles back comfortably in his seat to enjoy the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the doors we see a taxi pulling away and presently a glass door opens and a dishevelled Ben comes into the lobby. He comes up to the CAMERA and looks about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his viewpoint the lobby appears empty except perhaps for a solitary uniformed policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben look the other way and upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his viewpoint the other direction -- just emptiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Ben's bewilderment as to what to do and where to go. We PAN him up to the first corridor entrance that leads to the main circular corridor. Ben enters. His face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his viewpoint we see through the opening the ticket collector and the program girl standing at the opening leading down the main aisle. On the right, standing with her back to him, is Jo. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANS Ben as he hurries forward. He touches Jo lightly on the shoulder. She turns, startled, and manages to suppress an exclamation on seeing him. We do not hear what they are saying but by their pantomime we see that Jo is telling Ben all about the impending shooting. Ben argues with her. He indicates he will tell Buchanan. She frantically restrains him but he shakes her off and dashes away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Ben ascending the stairs originally taken by the dignitary and his group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben comes into the corridor and looks about him. Beyond him we see a group of men obviously detectives, and ahead of them a police constable. We see Ben hurry in his direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben comes up to the constable and is about to pass him when he is stopped. We again do not hear the dialogue, but the pantomime shows that Ben is trying to get to Buchanan. The constable doesn't quite know what to make of Ben's dramatic plea. He indicates that he must talk to his superior. Ben waits impatiently as the constable goes over to one of the Inspectors who is standing in a small group a little way off. From his viewpoint we see the constable addressing the Inspector with skeptical nods of his head in Ben's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo, looking over her shoulder and then up to the box of the dignitary. She turns desperately towards the direction of the Assassin's box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another view of the orchestra, but the duration of it on the screen is much quicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flash of the Violins. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flash of the cellos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quick flash of the brass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A timpani section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cymbals still laying on the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector is turning to Ben, the Constable on one side. Again in pantomime the Inspector questioning the impatient Ben. He leaves Ben and goes over to the men standing outside the door to the box. Ben half- turns away with exasperation toward the CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conductor in the foreground.    We see a quick shot of the orchestra beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The singers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The timpani.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a different angle the cymbals filling the screen. CAMERA PULLS BACK quickly and the man who is to wield them unfolds his arms and uncrosses his legs. He leans forward to glance at his  score.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is still waiting for the Inspector to discuss matters with the plainclothesman. He turns and hurries away, the CAMERA PANNING him. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo is almost weeping with the effect of the singing and the emotional stress she is going through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the orchestra, the cymbal player now places one hand on the cymbals on the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the box the Assassin places his hand for the   first time inside his coat towards his holster. The    CAMERA PULLS BACK to show the woman sitting with him,   seeing this gesture, rising and backing away into the   dark recesses of the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is now quickly listening into the section behind the boxes, one of which is occupied by the Assassin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben looks along the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his viewpoint we see rows of boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is a little nonplussed.   He approaches one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plainclothesmen and two uniformed policemen are now coming toward CAMERA looking for the departed Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the orchestra the conductor is wielding his baton vigorously. He swings over a sheet of music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The choir turns over their music. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cymbal player turns over his music. He looks at the music in front of him and for the first time picks up the cymbals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A closer view of Ben shows him trying another door cautiously and surreptitiously. He looks in and then softly closes the door. He moves further along and tries another door with the same cautious movement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Assassin now has his gun out in the darkness of the rear of the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cymbal player watching his music, his cymbals held.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his viewpoint with the cymbals tipping the bottom of the screen, we see all his music. It is blank. The CAMERA SWIFTLY MOVES IN to the bottom of the right- hand page showing the one note he is to strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo becoming more anxious and desperate. She looks up towards the Assassin's box with horror as she sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Assassin's figure moving forward and the tip of the gun for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conductor looks up towards the cymbal player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The player raises the cymbals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A close view of the poised gun in the Assassin's box. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                  1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben trying one more box door.   He again closes it and moves to one more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dignitary's pleased and smiling face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gun poised.   It fills the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cymbals are held in the foreground and through them we can see the orchestra and the conductor beyond. The conductor looks up from his score and points deliberately to the cymbal player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cymbals clash together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo leaping forward with a scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dignitary is clutching his arm and slumping forward. We gain an impression of those around leaping to their feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people around Jo, startled as they rise in their seats and turn back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben dashes to a final door and swinging it open finds himself face-to-face with the Assassin. The latter's hand goes for his holster. He pulls out his gun. Ben lunges forward with a blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Assassin staggers back and we hear the clatter of the gun as it falls to the floor. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 13 He immediately turns towards the CAMERA looking for a means of escape. He leaps to the edge of the box to go over into the next one. He slips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the Assassin fall with a crash into the aisle below him as Ben dashes forward in the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soprano singers in the middle of their note quickly change it to a unified scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music trails off as the orchestra rises to its feet at the startling occurrence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall is in an uproar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people   around the dignitary in his box are backing up to give   him air. Someone is examining his wound. He see by   his movements and a shake of his head that he is not   dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo is still standing looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From her viewpoint she sees Ben leaning over the box in horror looking down at the dead Assassin below. The door opens and the uniformed and plainclothes police dash into The box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is utter confusion in the lobby, police dashing upstairs on either side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Ben hurrying down the stairs. Jo rushes into the lobby and, seeing Ben, dashes towards him. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 13 A few of the people around the lobby begin to look at Jo and Ben. We see the Assistant Manager hurry over to them. They are in a group of three, and although we do not actually hear what he says, due to the hubbub, he is obviously questioning Ben and being solicitous to Jo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go close just in time to catch the tail-end of the conversation. Ben is just saying: BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he didn't kill him? ASSISTANT MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wife saved him -- it is only a small flesh wound...Oh here he is now...you must come and meet him...don't be nervous...I'll get the aide to present you...it will be all right (To Woburn) Would you present the lady to the prime minister? Suddenly their attention is drawn to something off- screen up the stairs. The hubbub increases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From their viewpoint we see the Prime Minister, obviously not wounded sufficiently to incapacitate, being escorted down the stairs by his Aide and other members of the staff, including Woburn of the Special Branch. The Prime Minister is indicating his arm and obviously by the way he waves his hands, is deprecating their concern about his wound. In fact he is rather over-doing it. Just beyond them at the top of the stairs we see 'Buchanan' standing with the Ambassador.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Buchanan' is reassuring the Ambassador. BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll report to you fully at the Embassy, Your Excellency. In the meantime...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager is leading Ben and Jo across to the foot of the stairs. They are reluctant but he insists. As the CAMERA PANS them over they meet the group at the bottom at the stairs. The manager calls out to Mr. Woburn and indicates Ben and Jo. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org              135.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woburn is a little non-plussed.  He leans over to one of the Prime Minister's Aides.  The latter's face lights up. He leans over and whispers  something to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister is  all smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woburn steps down and introduces Ben and Jo to the Prime Minister's Aide. WOBURN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Prime Minister, this is the lady who -- The Prime Minister interrupts enthusiastically. PRIME MINISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear lady, I shall be for ever in your debt. WOBURN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is her husband -- The Prime Minister interrupts again, less enthusiastically. PRIME MINISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasure, my dear sir... (He turns to Jo) I trust you will permit me to wait upon you tomorrow and to express the depth of my gratitude. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Weakly) It wasn't -- it wasn't -- PRIME MINISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Gallantly) Oh but it was, my dear lady. There is an awkward pause.  The Prime Minister collects himself and turns to move on out of the hall, the police making a passageway for him through the crowd. We see the Ambassador hurrying into the picture and moving across the screen quickly to follow the Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Jo stand for a moment not knowing what to do or where to go next. Woburn standing with Ben and Jo. They look up and see Buchanan. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 13 WOBURN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Mr. Buchanan would like to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From their viewpoint a grim 'Buchanan' is standing at the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANS Ben and Jo up the stairs towards 'Buchanan'. They increase their pace towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they reach him they have only one thought in their minds to ask him. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Wildly) Where's our boy?   Where's Hank? BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) We can talk if you'll come in here. The CAMERA PANS the three across the top landing and to the doors of the 'Green Room' There are various police standing about and some of Special Branch men can be seen inside the room. 'Buchanan' steps aside too allow Jo to enter. Then he and Ben follow her in. The door closes behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them enter the 'Green Room', generally used by the principal Artistes appearing at Royal Albert Hall. Buchanan nods to two Special Branch men who are standing about in case they are needed. The room is informal containing arm chairs, a sofa and a number of small tables. Jo sits down wearily into the nearest chair. Ben remains standing, Buchanan takes a seat in a chair near a telephone, he looks up at Ben as if he expects him to say something. Ben responds to the look. BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Coldly) So you both know the time and place all along. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Roughly) Don't be a fool. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                137 BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An odd coincidence -- both of you turning up here. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Coldly) Too bad you didn't contact your assistant. He sent us both here. BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quickly) I beg your pardon. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, we finally needed that help you offered. We still need it. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Urgently) Yes, Mr. Buchanan.     We still need it. The door opens and another member of the Special Branch enters. DETECTIVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir? Buchanan nods to him to speak. DETECTIVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've questioned the woman. Said she bought a ticket that happened to place her in the same box with the man that did the shooting. Doesn't know anything -- but if she does, she's not talking. BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see her later. DETECTIVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, sir. The Detective exits as Ben sits down dejectedly in a chair. BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Gently) Please tell me everything, now. Everything. (go turns to Jo) There's still plenty of room for hope, Mrs. McKenna...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high CAMERA shows us a large hallway and ornate ballroom. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                138 As yet the room is about quarter filled and various guests of the Diplomatic Corps and others are gradually adding to the group. The CAMERA DOLLIES DOWN over them until it reaches slightly open doorway. Peering cautiously through we see the face of Drayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other side of the doorway is Drayton and his wife. She is pacing nervously behind him. A footman comes up to them and announces: FOOTMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Excellency will see you now. Drayton motions to his wife and the CAMERA PANS them after the footman across a small hallway. He is the very same footman we saw among the group of servants who were herded out of the kitchen. He opens a door in front of the Draytons -- they enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing in front of a fireplace, above which is an oil painting of the Prime Minister, is the Ambassador whom we saw at the Albert Hall. He is on the telephone. AMBASSADOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...yes...I see. Well if the woman won't talk, she won't talk and that's that, I suppose. All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Drayton closes the door behind the two as Drayton advances towards the Ambassador with an easy manner, the CAMERA PANNING him. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Easily) Excuse me sir, I have a lot to explain to you -- something very unusual has happened. I must also have the money to pay our French marksman. AMBASSADOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Almost casually) Wouldn't it be superfluous, considering that he's dead? Drayton and his wife stare mutely at the Ambassador. They are staggered at this news. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org               139. AMBASSADOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His aim wasn't quite as good as you led me to expect. The target merely received a slight flesh wound in the arm. Worse than useless. Drayton still stares, petrified, at the Ambassador. AMBASSADOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then your French friend panicked, and made a fatal crash -- landing on the floor of the Albert Hall. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Blustering weakly) I don't see how you can hold me responsible. He was most warmly recommended by our people in Marrakesh... The Ambassador now begins to get really nasty. AMBASSADOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you're able to treat the matter so lightly. I am holding a reception here this evening. In a few minutes, I have to welcome our Prime Minister as my guest of honor -- when I hope and expected that he would be totally unable to attend. That amuses you, no doubt? DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Feebly) I don't know what to say ... AMBASSADOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Brutally) No. But I do. You've muddled everything from the start. Kidnapping that child in Marrakesh...Don't you realize that Americans dislike having their children kidnapped? DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Trying to keep his end up) How else could I make sure the American would hold his tongue? AMBASSADOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Ignoring this) And then, to crown it all, you get cold feet and come running along here to hide -- and bring the child with you: Don't you see what you've done to the diplomatic status of this Embassy? Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 14 DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Weakly) I didn't think...I only thought... AMBASSADOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Staccato) How are you going to get the child out of here, eh? Eh? Eh? Eh? DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Struggling for self-confidence) There's no difficulty about that, surely? The car -- AMBASSADOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Interrupting) With plain-clothes detectives planted right round this building? (Wryly) You English intellectuals will be the death of us all. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Desperate) I'll think of some method.   Just give me time.... AMBASSADOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (He snorts Contemptuously) Time! The Ambassador paces a moment, suppressing his rage, and then he stops and looks at Drayton as if thinking about something. AMBASSADOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want the child removed from this Embassy, and removed in such a way that he won't be able to say any more where he has been tonight. MRS. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no! The Ambassador pauses and looks up at her in such a manner that she almost shrinks. She tries to say something, but no words come out of her half-open mouth. Drayton, however, answers the Ambassador with horrible servility. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, I'll see to it.. Lucy Drayton looks at her husband with loathing. There is a polite tap on the door. The Ambassador looks up. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. The door opens and a butler enters. BUTLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Excellency, the Princess should be arriving at any moment. The Ambassador braces himself, his       chest swells out little, h assumes a set smile and       strides from the room. Just at this moment we hear        a String Orchest in the distance strike up some gay       waltz music. The Ambassador goes out of the door.        Mrs. Drayton is looking down at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is talking.    Buchanan is listening carefully. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...recognized him, and he recognized me. So he jumped for it. And that is all. BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Slowly) Trying to liquidate one of their own big-shots. I wish they'd stick to their usual custom, and do it in their own country... At this moment the phone rings. Woburn, who is now re- placing the two Special Branch men in the room, picks up the telephone. WOBURN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. (He listens for a moment) Hold on. He turns the telephone over to Buchanan. BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To phone) Buchanan speaking. Buchanan listens for a while, his face changing as he listens with increased interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.    Bye. Buchanan hangs up, turns to Woburn, but half speaks in the direction of the McKenna's. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 14 BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Draytons are at the Embassy. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know? BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have ways of finding out -- from the inside. Ben almost shouts as he gets up from his chair. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the Draytons are at the Embassy, Hank has to be there too! Buchanan turns his attention back to Ben. BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Grimly) You're probably right.   But we can do nothing. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't you? BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every Embassy in a foreign country has extra-territorial rights. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean in common language? BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far as we're concerned, this Embassy stands on foreign soil. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that mean they can steal children and get away with it? BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could have the Foreign Office serve a writ on the Ambassador. He breaks off and speaks apologetically as If it were I parenthesis. BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You know, I'm not responsible for the complications of International Law... He resumes: BUCHANAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...If only we had positive proof that the boy really is in there. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org               143. As they are talking Ben is thinking hard, obviously hatching some scheme in his mind. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the telephone number of this Embassy. Both of the men looking at Ben a moment without answering and then Woburn speaks first. WONBURN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grosvenor 0144. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you thinking about, Ben? Without answering Jo, Ben picks up the 'phone. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grosvenor 0144. Ben looks at the group briefly.   Buchanan looks at Ben with keen curiosity. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to speak to the Minister himself. Buchanan looks intrigued and surprised. We hear the answering click on the other end of the phone. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I speak to the Prime Minister, please? There is a pause and the distorted sound of a voice mumbling on the other end of the phone. Ben interrupts the question. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him the lady who saved his life wants to speak to him. Its important. The voice on the other end of the phone mumbles briefly, and there is silent. Ben has a satisfied look on his face, as he hands the receiver to Jo. She seems frightened. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to say, Ben? I don't know -- (She trails off) Ben, half looking at Woburn and Buchanan, gives her instructions. BFN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he wanted to visit us soon so he could thank you. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 14 BFN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, tell him we'd like to see him tonight, at the Embassy, because we have to leave London tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the Ambassador's study underneath the oil painting of himself, the Prime Minister is escorted to a telephone by the butler who hands him the instrument. Having been told who was on the other and of the line he is all smiles as he greets Jo. PRIME MINISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear lady...This is a charming surprise... He listens to the other end of the phone, agreeably making sounds such as "ah ha" "ah" "hum", then he speaks, with a gracious sweep of his hand and a half bow to the telephone. PRIME MINISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delighted, delighted, delighted. The Ambassador, too, will be delighted. Any friends of mine are friends of his. We will drink a little toast to your country and to mine. Peacefully we will co-exist...Yes? He looks up to admire the painting of himself on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo hangs up the phone, a little surprised and still considerably nervous. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Ben) He said -- all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi pulls up in the front of the large, old-fashioned Embassy. The windows are brightly lighted, evidence of a social occasion. Ben and Jo get out of the taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben pays the driver, takes Jo's arm, and they start up the steps of the Embassy. The CAMERA PANS them. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                145

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben presses the doorbell. His grip on Jo's's arm slides down to her hand. He holds it tightly. The door opens, and a liveried man ushers them in with gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter a large hallway. The liveried man closes the door. Standing in a nearby doorway is a group of people listening to the music of a string quartet playing in the room beyond. Included in the group is the Personal Aide of the Prime Minister. He sees Jo and Ben enter, hurries over to them, smiling and eager. The piece that the string quartet is playing ends amid a round of polite applause. There are people rising from their chairs and a general movement out into the hallway. AIDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good even. Would you come this way, please? The Prime Minister is waiting for you. Following the Aide, Ben and Jo squeeze through the crowded doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Aide leads Ben and Jo through the main room, the CAMERA DOLLIES them. As they move through the room people begin to notice them, first of all because they are not dressed for the occasion -- but then the looks seem to be admiring ones, and there is a smattering of applause at their passage. Apparently people recognize them. The Aide takes them to the Prime Minister, who is just getting up from his seat of honor in the first row.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prime Minister recognizes them immediately, and comes forward quickly to meet them. PRIME MINISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Effusively) Good evening, good evening! The Ambassador is behind the Prime Minister, and the Prime Minister turns to him with enthusiasm. PRIME MINISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the charming lady who saved my life at the Concert! Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org             146. The Ambassador comes forward quickly, all smiles. AMBASSADOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Suavely) Madame, you saved the life of the one man, who is irreplaceable in our Country. PRIME MINISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Suddenly to Jo) They tell me you are the famous Jo Conway, Madame? JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   I'm Jo Conway. PRIME MINISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Ben) Do you think perhaps Madame might be persuaded to sing? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I'm sure she would be glad to... wouldn't you dear? JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know.     It's been some time... PRIME MINISTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg you, Madame. A tranquil coda to conclude a dramatic evening! JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.   I'm very flattered. AMBASSADOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To butler) Stanis would you put up some chairs quickly. (To guests) Ladies and gentlemen, we have with us tonight...Jo Conway...the famous Jo Conway...she has graciously consented to sing for us .. (To his wife) Darling would you see that the Prime Minister has a very good seat. They move off to seats -- Jo is led to piano by Ambassador. Aide crosses to Ben. AIDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to sit down, sir? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...I'll just stand over here. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                147

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Discreetly, Ben moves away from the group, and over toward a side wall, the CAMERA PANNING HIM. All eyes are on Jo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo adjusts herself at the piano. Her face seems serious. She looks up briefly with her eyes to check where Ben is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people in the hallway, realizing there is to be more entertainment, move toward the main room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tries out the keys of the Piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are finding their seats. There is coughing, shuffling of feet, and then a gradual hush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben watches Jo, and at the same time seems to be lookIng around the room, particularly toward the various exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having strummed a few notes, Jo settles down and plays the introduction to her song. We see the great tenseness on her face, interposed with Professional smiles, which she bestows on those nearest her, but always the tenseness returns. As she sings, her voice seem to be rather overpowering. It fills the whole room with quite a volume. It almost seems out of place that she has become so professional in such an intimate drawing room setting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in the ballroom is listening intently, and with surprise, at her singing. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 14

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hallway, showing people crowded at the door, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first landing on the flight of stairs above the hallway. No one is around. Jo's voice loses some of its volume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A higher stairway landing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A second floor corridor, deserted.    Jo's voice fading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door at the end of the corridor. We now hear the song floating up clearly, but much diminished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a room on the other side of the door, Hank McKenna is listening to the music. Hank seems a little puzzled. Then, his face lights up and he jumps suddenly to his feet. He runs towards the door and begins trying to open it. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my Mother's voice!    That's my Mother singing! Mrs. Drayton is quite startled by Hank's performance. MRS. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank -- are you sure? Are you really sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank turns around at the doorway, to look at Mrs. Drayton. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's her!    I know it! Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 14

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Drayton's face, still awed by what she has heard. MRS. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is she doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank, a little mystified, has no answer. He walks slowly back into the room, towards Mrs. Drayton, listening and thinking about what he hears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Drayton's face shows a new and dangerous thought coming into it. She looks down at Hank. MRS. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank? -- can you whistle that song?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her and nods abstractedly. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so. She kneels down quickly to him. MRS DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then go on -- whistle it.   Whistle it as loud as you can. On Hank's face comes a little understanding. He can barely believe what she means. Then he understands. He turns, and deliberately facing the door, starts to whistle the song. He whistles loud and vigorously. Mrs. Drayton stands up and moves back to a chair, as she watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down in the ballroom, Jo is looking up anxiously as she sings. She deliberately breaks and pauses for a moment and softens her accompaniment. Then she hears it -- a faint whistle coming from above, not enough for those around to appreciate it, but loud enough for the straining ears of Jo. She looks across the ballroom to find Ben, and her eyes go up. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 15

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching her, Ben understands.   He gives her the slightest sign of agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jo continues her song with almost excitement in her singing voice. The CAMERA passes around her as it follows Ben as he walks along the wall slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben makes his way along the wall toward the far doorway, which leads to the grand staircase Everyone is so intent on listening to Jo, that his movement attracts no attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bottom of the service stairs in the back of the Embassy, Drayton is standing with two men who came with him in the car. One of them holds a short length of rope in his hand. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two wait in the mail room.   I'll bring him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben mounts two stairs leading up to the grand staircase. He looks about him cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the service stairs, Drayton goes up two stairs and turns back to the men. He looks at his watch. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be a minute. He starts to move up one step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up in the room, Hank is bent in a chair, sobbing, Mrs. Drayton is kneeling by him, trying to reassure him. She stops suddenly as she hears footsteps in the distance. She rises to her feet, and as the footsteps grow and grow, she looks at the boy desperately, She goes to the door, hears the steps coming nearer and nearer. She looks across at the window. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barred window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks down at Hank almost protectively, as  the footsteps get still nearer. She goes to Hank,   kneels down again and clutches the boy to her as the  footsteps stop outside the door. She looks at the door,   with horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door handle turns quietly, but firmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Drayton lets out a piercing scream. Hank's head jerks up. The door is heard bursting open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ban stands in the doorway. He instantly rushes toward Hank, the CAMERA PANNING him. Hank leaps to his feet, and the two of them come together. No clear words are spoken, Just muffled sounds of words as they hug each other. Then they release each other, and turn to look at Mrs. Drayton. She is standing, staring at the door with horror. Ben turns quickly to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Framed in the doorway is Drayton. Deftly he reaches into his pocket and produces a small automatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment the group stands there in silence.    Then Ben speaks. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you want to start any shooting, Drayton -- with all those people downstairs, and police outside. Drayton looks at him without saying anything, but the gun doesn't lower. Mrs. Drayton addresses her husband fiercely. MRS. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to let the boy go! Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                  1 DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precisely my own notion, my dear. He moves forward on   the group, gun poised. Hank clutches his father   in fright, and Ben tenses himself, prepared for battle   if necessary. Mrs. Drayton stares at her husband with   some defiance. Drayton addresses Ben amiably. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you'll ba sensible, and help me out of here? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask me for help, you miserable....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drayton seems unperturbed by Ben's refusal. He leans down closer to the boy, and addresses him directly. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't want your father to get hurt, would you? Hank looks up towards his father.    Drayton looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drayton's intentions are unmistakable. Ben looks down at him with a hatred that is almost ready to explode, but he has sense enough to understand Drayton's meaning. Drayton straightens up, a slight smile on his face. He slips the gun into his pocket, but still holds it. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go down the stairs   together in a casual sort of way. Then    we'll stroll along to the nearest taxi   rank. I trust there won't be any   emotional outbursts... BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Interrupting) There won't be. Hank -- don't say or do anything. Hank just nods.   He's too frightened to talk. DRAYTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we go? Ben starts for the door with Hank, and Drayton moves into the other side of Hank. As they go through the door, Mrs. Drayton makes an instinctive step forward, if to attack Drayton from the rear, but the sight of Hank in danger stops her. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org                 15

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trio, Hank in the center, slowly strolls down the corridor toward the main stairway. The sound of Jo Conway's voice can be heard from below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING FROM BELOW we see the big staircase empty for a moment, then the three appear at the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A closer view shows the terrified, tear-stained face of Hank, and the tense features of Ben. Drayton seems carefully alert. The CAMERA MOVES DOWNWARD in front of them as they descend. The music coming from the ballroom ceases, as Jo finishes her second song. There is the sound of great applause. The three are about a dozen steps from the bottom, when suddenly Ben shoots out a hard and pushes Drayton forward. Taken by surprise, he stumbles, and falls down the stairs clumsily. Clutching for support with his hands, the gun goes off in his pocket, and he remains in a crumpled heap at the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The applause having died out, the shot is heard loud, and people pour out of the ballroom into the hallway. They rush for the stairway, and Drayton's body, led by the Ambassador and the Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As people crowd excitedly around the body, Ben is hurrying Hank away from the scene, the CAMERA PANS them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Drayton stops half-way down the stairway, and looks down in shook at the sight of her dead husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the ballroom, which is emptying due to the rush of people to the corridor, Jo has risen from the piano and is almost afraid to go out and see what has happened. In a moment, Ben and the boy appear in  the doorway. Hank rushes across the ballroom to his  mother, who moves quickly when she sees him. Converted to PDF by www.screentalk.org              154. HANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummy. JO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank. They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the McKenna's hotel room, the Parnells and the two woman guests are sprawled out in ungainly attitudes of sleep. Val is snoring pleasantly. The door of the room opens and the three McKennas appear. The sound awakes Val. He peers at them sleepily and struggles to a sitting position. Ben closes the door. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry we were gone so long, Val, but we had to go and pick up Hank. Ben's voice awakens the other women. They sit up, and stare with bewilderment at the smiling trio of Ben, Jo and Hank.
